conbody.p: A Policy CDR is not generated automatically. CDR generation can be enabled using rule actions. Each event type has an action corresponding to its trigger. If the action appears in the results, then the CDR is logged. They can be used in conjunction with any condition to utilize the criteria under which the CDR for that event type can be logged.
Policy CDRs can be enabled to log CDRs for policy under the appropriate trigger using the rule actions.

note.p: To include the current timestamp (GMT time) as part of the CDR, add the attribute <include attribute="timestamp"/> to the event being logged. To include the local timestamp (local time) as part of the CDR, add the attribute <include attribute="localtimestamp"/> to the event being logged.

conbody.p: Some attributes encode lists of multiple values. The pieces are encoded using different separators like hash tag (“#”) and colon (':') by default. These separators are defined in the Global Configuration application preferences: CDR Sub-Field Separator1 and CDR Sub-Field Separator2.

note.p: EDRs in policy are generated in the /cdr/mvno1/edr directory with .edr format.

To permanently run this, add the command (for example, export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.171-7.b10.el7.x86_64/jre/), along with the latest example of JAVA version to the bash.rc profile.
